Special express Itinerary arriving Piracus Friday evenings and Constantinople Saturday afternoon omitting, Smyrna and Mitylene ontwards.
PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.

The fast steamers Assouan, Minieh and Menzaleh leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina calling fortnightly at Larnaca (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli, and Constantinople.
SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.
The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.
RED SEA COATSTING MAIL SERVICE.
Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai) Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

div.head: BIRTH.
div.p: MORE-On June 8, at Glandore, Temple Gardens, Dublin, the wife of Richard E. More (Khartum), of a daughter.

div.head: COTTON INDUSTRY IN LANCASHIRE.
div.p: A change has come over the staple industry of Lancashire during the past few months. To-day things have come to such a pass in the weaving section that manufacturers are more disposed to stop a few weeks than to keep machinery fully employed. This state of things has been going on for a couple of months or so. All this year makers of piece goods who use bought yarn have been experiencing a narrower margin owing to the advancing tendency of yarn at a time when the supply of cop-twist and weft has been scarcely sufficient for the required consumption of the looms. Sellers of yarn have been enabled to obtain full quotations. Higher raw cotton has meant higher yard prices, in short, spinners have kept their margin of profit pretty well, regardless of the narrowing margin of cloth producers.

The cloth demand from the great consuming markets of the East has fallen off, and orders have only been obtainable in comparatively small lots at prices not in keeping with yarn values. The result of it all is that to-day the loom section dependable on bought yam is in a depressed state, and in numerous cases it is felt that the best policy under the circumstances is to lessen the consumption of yarn by stopping and also decreasing the production of cloth and so relieve the market. At Whitsuntide this year, when the looms are usually idle for a few days, arrangements were made in Blackburn and other districts to extend the holidays several days. This did not assist the market, no steps are being taken in Burnley, which is a big manufacturing district, to close down a whole fortnight before the middle of next month. This is looked upon as a drastic step, and it tells its own tale. There are 80,000 looms in that centre, and a fortnight's stoppage means a reduced consumption of yarn to the extent of nearly 8,000,OOO lb. It is estimated that it would take fifty spinning mills of average size, say 100,000 spindles, to produce this weight in a fortnight. The Accrington district, which has nearly 30,000 looms, is about to adopt some such policy as has been agreed upon in Burnley. Other towns are following suit, such as Bacup.

Whilst all this short time is being worked in weaving, the spinning trade is folly employed on yarn contracts entered into some months ago. Spinners to-day have a good margin of profit in most counts and qualities, on every pound of yam they may sell. A feature is that the spinning holidays are observed later on in the season. A matter of interest has been that the export demand for the Continent has strengthened the position of spinners lately.But for that Urge trade it is thought that spinners would have found their position by now less satisfactory than a month or two ago. It almost seems from what is going on, that yarn has seen its best days. There is sure to be a material lessening of consumption, and on the other hand spinners are bringing more yam upon the market by the gradual starting of new milLs. Spinners have a more perfect organization than the weaving employers, and it remains to be seen what steps the Federation of spinning employers will take as to running lessened time in case the weaving short time becomes widespread. It would not come as a surprise if the Federation, finding their margin slipping away, stopped the spindles for a stated period. It is probable that there will be a struggle between the spindles and the looms during the next three or four months.

Trade generally, so far as the consumption of goods abroad is concerned, may be described as healthy. The higher prices will, no doubt, restrict operations, but customers abroad are on the whole doing very well, and the outlook in India is not at all unsatisfactory. For a couple of months past India has bought very little cloth. She possesses large supplies, but dealers in Bombay and Calcutta have hesitated about following the higher course of values. Then she has awaited the monsoon rains. These rains which have been expected for a week past, set in at Bombay on Wednesday last, and if the downpour be general in the Dependency the crops will be assured, and business in piece goods with Lancashire will probably be immediately resumed. China is over supplied, but the stocks there are running down. Egypt and Turkey, as well as South America, take largely from us. Indeed, during the last few years they have increased their imports considerably.

All is uncertainty as to the probable American crop next season, which commences on Aug. 1st. In the meantime there is plenty of cotton to go round. If the American yield be as large as the last, then all will be well for the County Palatine, but if it should prove to be a small crop, as two years ago, then there will not be enough raw material to keep the spindles of the world running full time.

div.head: The Ionian Bank.
div.p: The Alexandrian branch of this bank is to be housed in Rue Debhane in the new Antonuiadis Buildings.

div.head: Hashish Smugglers
div.p: The police seized a bale of cotton containing 50 kilos of hashish concealed in the interior, in the vicinity of Rod el Farag during Friday night, and arrested a certain French subject named Levy and a Greek named Meneas in connection with the case.

div.head: A Yemen Rumor.
div.p: The Turkish Embassy in London contradicts a report from Cairo that a large number partisans of Ibn Saul have entered Medina, owing to the paucity of the Imperial garrison and the sympathy of the townspeople with the Wahabis, and that it is feared that Ibn Saul will shortly attack Medina.

div.head: Desperate Step
div.p: A native student attempted suicide on Friday in the Darb el Ahmar, Cairo, by stabbing himself in the abdomen. The wound was fortunately not fatal and the patient will have to remain in hospital for a month or so. The motive of the attempt is supposed to bd extreme poverty.

div.head: New P. and 0. Steamer
div.p: The Peninsular and Oriental Company have contracted with Messrs. Caird and Co., of Greence for an express mail steamer for their branch service between Bombay and Aden, run in connection with their China and Australia line. The vessel will be purely a mail and passenger boat with a minimum of cargo space, but accommodation for nearly three hundred first and second class passenger.

div.head: Tramway Accidents
div.p: About midday on Friday last a certain Ahmed Mohammed Abdallah, in attempting to descend from the tram while passing through the Khalig, missed his footing and sustained a fall which bruised him severely, and will necessitate nearly a month's treatment in the hospital. On the evening of the same day a similar accident occurred to a native who attempted to alight from a tram in motion in the Bah el Louk Square.

div.head: Governorship of Malta
div.p: In a petition which is being circulated in Malta, the name of Major-General Barron, the senior military officer, is recommended to the Foreign Office for the Governorship. The petition declares that the appointment of Major-General Barron would render great service to the cause of special unity in Malta, and would give considerable impetus to harmonious cooperation between the English and Maltese, which is so desirable for the promotion of the interests of the Colony.

div.head: The Decisions To Take
div.p: The crisis has shown that under social circumstances it is necessary to take without hesitation a decision dictated by the events. Those who have much time on their hands during the summer months can occupy it very usefully by a study of either French, English, German, Italian, Greek or Arabic, in the Berlitz School, which has opened a branch in the Carlton Hotel, Ramleh (rez-de-chausee) for the convenience of those who are going to pass the summer there. (Advt.)

div.head: Cattle Plague.
div.p: During the week ending the 17th instant 418 fatal cases of bovine typhushave been reported in the whole of Egypt The analysis shows 27 deaths in the Beni Mazar district, 6 in the Fachn district, 115 in the Abou Kerkas district, 9 in Minieh, 57 in Samalout, 8 at Maghaga, 2 in Beni Souef, 13 at Beba, 2 at Wasta, 10 in the Fayoum Province, 6 at Sennoures, l at Abou Tig, 3 at Abnoub, 32 at Manfalout, 83 at Deirout, 30 at Mallawi, I at Belbeis 1 At Zagazig, 2 at Hgeia, 1 at Sanbe and 6 at Kalioub.

div.head: Young Lady Disappears
div.p: A young lady, daughter of a well-known Cairo resident, and aged 17 years, has mysteriously disappeared from her parents house in the Tewfikieh quarter. She left the house on Friday evening accompanied by a governess about six o'clock and has not been seen since. The neighbours have said that she mounted a motor-car at the Rond Point Tewfik, but the young bey, with whom the girl had been in secret correspondence denies any knowledge of the matter. The story of the automobile is discredited and she is believed to be safely housed in Cairo.

div.head: Cairo's Streets
div.p: The state of the Cairo streets often leaves much to be desired. Last week, while Mrs. Bailey, a lady nurse, and Dr. Menasce were driving in the night along Sharia Abbas to an urgent case of hemorrage, their carriage drove into a mound of stones piled up in the middle of the road. The concussion was so severe that the nurse was laid up owing to the shock. A correspondent writes :—"The Esbekieh Police Station was informed immediately after the accident by the doctor and Mrs. Bailey, but they never even took the trouble to go as far as the spot and see for themselves this neglect of the Tanzim. In fact the policeman on that beat ought to have seen this irregularity removed before an accident occurred."

div.head: THE BOURSE REOPENED.
div.p: The Alexandria Bourne was re-opened this morning. The fall in securities continues and the depression is general.

div.head: THE CASSA DI SCONTO.
div.p: Yesterday at the request of the council, representing the Union Bank at Vienna and the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio, judgement on the application for a 'sequestre judiciaire" was postponed. This morning Mr. Metaxa of the Union Bank at Vienna, arrived at Alexandria from Trieste by the Austrian Lloyd steamer,--having come here for the purpose of enquiring into the position of the Cassa. Mr. Metaxa is well-known in Austria as a financier and has a high reputation in banking circles in Vienna, he belongs to an old and respected Greek fandly, He is the brother of Mr D.G. Metaxa, who is the Hellenic Ambassador at the Court of St James's, and the brother-in-law of Mrs. Constantine Sinadino, Mrs. Salvago of Alexandria, and of Mrs. Athanasius Vagliano of Paris.

div.head: BANKRUPTCY RUMOURS.
div.p: No new bankruptcy petition was presented at the Alexandria Mixed Courts last week. A crop of rumours have been going about to the effect that there was to be a number of petitions for today, but the news is devoid of any foundation.
The first vacation sitting of the Mixed Commercial Court, which deals with bankruptcy petitions, will take place on July 9th. No petition for this sitting has up to today been presented.

div.head: LONDON OPINION.
div.p: The "Statist" in commenting on the crisis in Egypt, draws attention to the country's great prosperity and remarks: "It is a natural result of all this (prosperity) that speculation should have become rampant, that new companies should have been manufactured on a rash wale, and that many of the new companies should be bogus concerns. The banks, it is understood, have from the first set their faces against a large number of these new companies. Certain private bankers and private capitalists have financed them; but the great banks, Egyptian, British and French, have set their faces against them, and it is believed that they have of late been putting pressure upon their customers to take insail. The result is a further fall and some failures. It has been alleged that some of these failures will hit Paris severely. We believe this is a mistake so far as the banks are concerned, the banks as we have already said, having carefully refrained from financing all sorts of unsafe new companies. But it is possible, of course, that speculators in Paris may have been hit, and it is also possible that private capitalists may have been hit. However, so far as we can understand, the losses will fall chiefly upon operators in Egypt itself. The "Daily Telegraph," of the 18th inst., in reviewing the state of the London Stock Exchange for the week, says :—

"While only a couple of insignificant failures have taken place in the Stock Exchange this week, further heavy losses, it is to be feared, have been incurred by many brokers, owing to financial difficulties in Egypt, which have reacted on London through Paris. For some time back trouble had been looked for, as the outcome of the land and bank speculation in Egypt, and its arrival should be no surprise. Apparently, however, two of the official agents de change in Paris have become involved with Alexandria clients, hence the recent selling of Rio Tinto, De Beers, and other securities."
"The Tribune" says :—

"The situation in Egypt naturally continues to be the subject of considerable discussion in financial circles. Cables received yesterday from that country intimated that the difficulties were confined to the bourse, and that further liquidation of speculative accounts was likely to take place. The commercial position, however, is said to be sound and the value of agricultural land maintained, while a large cotton crop is looked for. The elimination of the weak speculative element will undoubtedly prove beneficial, and if the trouble does not extend to the commercial community an early recovery is not improbable."

div.head: KHARTOUM'S ICE SUPPLY
div.p: Several complaints have been made about the ice supply of Khartoum and its sister cities. The arbitrary regulations adopted for its sale, making it impossible for a purchaser to buy less than a kilo, are commented upon but not regarded as much of a serious grievance compared with the quality of the ice itself. It is made of unfiltered water, and contains much sand and other impurities—organic and inorganic. It taints the purity of the water or any other beverage with which it is used ; and is regarded as a menace to the public health. The suggestion is made that the ice manufacturing company might, without imperilling its financial stability, invest a few pounds in the purchase of zeers or filters or the installation of a filtering plant, and the cause of complaint will thereby be completely removed.

div.head: CAIRO BRITISH RIFLE CLUB.
div.p: Members are hereby notified that from July 1st until further notice, the ranges at Tourah will be open for shooting on Fridays only. Members who have not yet paid their subsrciptions for season 1906 7 are requested to do so as soon as possible.

div.head: LONDON EGYPTIAN MARKET. CESSATION OF REALISATION. THE BANKS RALLYING
div.p: Active realisations in Egyptians are said to have ceased on Saturday. The banks have a tendency to rally and there was a large humber of bargains in Nationals which hardened to 17 1/4.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive embarked on the "Mahroussa" on Saturday evening about 7 o'clock, accompanied by Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan, Fakhry Pasha, Boutros Pasha Ghali, Zeky Pasha, and Mohamed Izzet Pasha, all of whom dined with his Highness, who set sail for Constantinople at midnight. Those accompanying the Khedive on his voyage are Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan, Fakhry Pasha, Zeky Pasha, and Mohamed Izzet Pasha.
The Khedivah and her children also embarked on the "Mahroussa."
Lewa Thurneyssen Pasha, Equerry to the Khedive, is leaving Alexandria on Thursday next to join his Highness at Vienna, where the Khedive will arrive about the 14th prox.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL COMPANY.
div.p: The general meeting of the Suez Canal shareholders adopted the report presented on behalf of the council of administration by Prince Auguste d'Arenberg.

Among the British members of the council of administration present at the meeting were the Hon. Reginald Lister, Sir Austin Lee, Mr. H.T. Anstruther, General Sir John Ardagh, Lord Rathmore, Sir T. Sutherland, and Messrs Green and Hughes. Mr. Donkin wrote regretting his absence owing to illness. M. Lepine, Prefect of Police, who was appointed to the council of administration, was presented to the shareholders.

Prince d'Arenberg, in addressing the meeting, surveyed the improvements introduced during the last ten years. He pointed out that since 1896 upwards of 36,000,000f.(£ 1,440,000) had been spent on widening and deepening the Suez Canal. The fine hospital of Port Said had been enlarged, and dispensaries had been established in connexion with that hospital and at Ismailia and at Port Tewfik, near Suez. At these institutions upwards of 120,000 patients had received treatment, and more than 500,000 consultations had been given. All those improvements bail been profitable, and the dividends, far from diminishing, had, on the contrary, increased. Alluding to the various rival canal schemes which periodically cropped up, Prince d'Arenberg pointed out that the company enjoyed by treaty a monopoly canal exploitation in the isthmus, and that consequently companies desirous of embarking on a rival enterprise would be obliged to go through the Jordan Valley, where they would encounter almost insuperable difficulties.
A shareholder asked whether the council of administration was not afraid of the Panama Canal's competing to a certain extent with the Suez Canal.

Prince d'Arenberg replied that very little American tonnage passed through the Suez Canal. Personally be believed that the Panama Canal would not affect the traffic of the Suez Canal. The more new routes were opened to commerce the more would traffic be increased and the more would the company profit.

On the motion of the council of administration the meeting unanimously ratified the appointment of the following new members of the council: — M. Lupine, Prefect of Police, in succession to the late M. Casimir Perier ; M. Denis Perouae, Inspector General of Roads and Bridges (retired), and formerly Director of Railways at the Ministry of Public Works, in succession to the late M. Julien Lefebvre.

div.head: KASSALA DISTRICT
div.p: The Irrigation Service is still occupied at Kassala with the allotment of lands to agriculturists, who are very keen about this matter this year, as they hope to be able to make up for their looses of the last year. Considerable damage was done to the cotton crop in the Kassala by field mice which ate the fresh holla or destroyed them. The crop hardly amounted to one half of what was exited. Mildew has done some damage to sagia crops, mostly melons, and watermelons.

div.head: MOSLEMS AND RED CROSS.
div.p: There is reason and justice in the request of the Turkish representative at the Red Cross Conference that Mahomedan countries should be permitted to adopt the Red Crescent instead of the Red Croat as the protective symbol for their ambulances and medical services. The symbol of the Cross is necessarily offensive to Mohamedans, especially if they happen to be engaged in warfare with a Christian power, and there seems no reason for objecting to the very natural request for some substitute. Anything which will promote humanity in warfare among the Eastern nations ought to be welcomed by those of Europe.

div.head: EGYPTIAN DELTA LAND AND INVESTMENT CO., LTD.
div.p: The following was the chairmans speech at the meeting of the above company held on Saturday afternoon:-
Gentlemen:

You will remember that at the General Meeting of the 16th April, confirmed by Meeting of the 7th May, both held in London, our Company was reconstituted on its original lines, and this is therefore the first Meeting held under these altered conditions though still an English Company you have no more London Board.
The accounts speak, I think, for themselves, and if any further information which is not contained in the report, and which I am in a position to give, is asked for, I am here to reply.

As you are fully aware, as far as the property market and general financial situation is concerned, Egypt is unfortunately under a cloud. Property sales are very rare and encashments of monies due on sales made are very difficult to obtain. A policy of waiting is absolutely imposed. This being the case, it may] he asked whether we have been wise in paying out as dividend our entire amount of profit realized and on this point I owe you an explanation.

When we come together next year, we shall have to divide our profits among a larger state holding ; though there is no intention of any public issue of new capital, a convention has been entered into with Messrs. Suares Freres & Cie whereby 10,000 s hares (jouissance 1st April 1907) are to be allotted to them in exchange for their land at Meadi and L 75,000 cash ; and as we wish to be absolutely fair both to the new shareholders and the old, we judged it only right to disregard the temptation of keeping monies already earned, however useful they may be in the present crisis and to pay away to the old shareholders all the profits actually Encashed up to the 31st March, the more so as sales already effected will, if payments are made to us on due date, enable us to distribute a substantial dividend again next year.

Gentlemen, you all know the financial, crisis through which Egypt in common with every other country in Europe and America is now going through. How long the crisis will last nobody could tell; but be it short or be it long, the end is bound to come and we will have a revival of confidence and active dealing in building lands. By this I do not mean to say that I look forward in the immediate future to a recurrence of the very high prices that were paid for last year for some suburban properties: but cheap building lands such as your Company holds are bound to sell at prices that will yield handsome profits. A glance at our printed report will show you that we held on 31st March 1907, 1,573,774 square metres of such lands costing a total sum of L E. 179,061, which is equal to P.T. 11 1/2 per square metre or adding 40% for roads P.T. 16 per square metre, amongst which area are included 60,000 square metres situated in various parts in the towns of Cairo, Tantah, etc., which even in these depressed times can be sold at an average equal to a good many times that figure.

As to what has taken place since closing these accounts, the property of Snares Freres & Cie adjoining ours at Meadi has been secured and we are already in possession. The property of Karkours has also been bought, but here we are not yet in possession, as the necessary formalities are not yet completed. These two purchases add another 730,000 square metres to our domain at Meadi.

As to our negotiations with the Government re the road, I regret that these have not gone on as satisfactorily as we could wish. Up to the present, the Finance Committee having only offered a sum of L.5,000 to improve the present Old Cairo road as far as Madabegh Station and this on condition that the Company provides at its own cost the site, and makes the remainder of the road, from Madabegh station onwards. The Public Works Department themselves have assured us that the amount is entirely insufficient for the purpose, so that we can only hope for a wore generous and practicable response to a modified offer we are now making to the Government. It is generally acknowledged that a road to Helouan is absolutely essential and must be made sooner or later, and I am therefore sanguine that the Government will not miss profiting by this opportunity of obtaining over 4 kilometres of this road made for nothing, as well as half the upkeep of a further large section which this Company is rawly to guarantee. Negotiations for electrifying the Cairo-Helouan Railways are well advanced and when completed, our Meadi Estate will certainly be enhanced in value.
In the meantime we are building a few villa houses, which we hope to have ready towards the end of the year or early in 1908, and are also developing and improving your property.

I move "that the report of the directors dated 13th instant, together with statement of accounts and balance sheet for the year ended 31st March 1907 be and they are hereby approved, confirmed and adopted."

div.head: THE ANGLO BELGIAN COMPANY OF EGYPT LTD.
div.p: The Anglo-Belgian Company of Egypt, Ltd. has just disposed of one its few remaining plots at Shoubrah at the very excellent figure of P.T. 900 per square metre with very favourable conditions of payment. Coming at such a moment this sale should be highly gratifying to the shareholders and give an excellent impression generally. It is worthy of note that the Anglo Belgian Company's recent transaction is practically unique, no other sales of suburban lots taring been recorded for some time, and the management is to be congratulated on a an excellent stroke of business.

div.head: INCREASING INFANT MORTALITY.
div.p: Some remarkable statistics are given by our Cairo contemporary "Journal du Cairo' on the infant mortality of Cairo. According to this paper within a quarter of a century the capital of Egypt will not contain one inhabitant. Needless to say the statistics given by our contemporary are based upon the figures recently given by the census and those of the statistical department for births and deaths. These are possibly equally erroneous, but at any rate it is obvious that the deductions of our contemporary are absolutely ridiculous be the cause what it may.

Working upon the said basis the writer of the article, taking the bulletins from May 25 to June 3, and from the 11th to the 17th June, finds that in the former period there were 487 births and 837 deaths, and in the latter period 462 births and 738 deaths. According to such figures the deaths in the Capital are at least 14,400 more than births, and, taking the census figures, viz 640,000, it only requires 44 years to leave Cairo without a single inhabitant.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit— within certain necessary limits— free discussion.

div.head: BATHING AT CLEOPATRA.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Dear Mr. Editor,—F. R. appears to be very indignant at the Jesuit Fathers' conduct as regards "their notices and other impediments put up on the spot from using the pool" at Cleopatra. What strikes me most in the gentleman's letter is not so much the cause of his grumbling, as the zeal wherewith he is animated to propagate by word and example his principles of Christian charity. His weapons are inverted commas and black paint. Talk of St. Paul teaching the Athenians tho mysteries of the unknown God, but F. R. preaching to the Jesuits beats anything of the sort. And supposing the good Fathers did listen to F. R., and took pattern by him; well, I fancy, they should have, in consequence, a very remarkable coating of his black paint Sir, 1 know nothing about the Jesuits, or about Cleopatra and its pool, but I am inclined to think, that it is not a white handkerchief that is working all the mischief in the imagination of bathers. Perhaps, the pool can boast of a red rag, and we all know the effect produced in the mind of those who are pugnaciously inclined by such a piece of stuff. Now F.R. get a wee bit hotter over the matter and the Jesuits stall, in conscience, be obliged to give you a cooling in their pool ; and, furthermore, try and make up your mind, ad Majorem Dei Gloriam, to get acquainted with these reverend gentlemen, for theirs is pre-eminently the art of raising one's charity above the freezing point and of inspiring people with tact and magnanimity. And don't be shy, please.
Yours truly,
Henry Hofmann.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS.
div.p: The King has been pleased to give and grant unto Major General St..George Charles Henry, C.B., his Majesty's Royal license and authority that lie may accept and wear the Insignia of the Second Class of the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Osmanieh, conferred upon him by his Highness the Khedive of Egypt, authorised by his Imperial Majesty the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered by him.

The King has been pleased to give and grant unto Lieu tenant Thomas Moffett Potts, R.N.R. (retired list,) his Majesty's Royal licence and authority that he may accept and wear the Insignia of the Fourth Class of the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Osmanieh, conferred upon him by his Highness the Khedive of Egypt, authorised by his Imperial Majesty the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered by him.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB.
div.p: The second meeting of the fifth season of the Alexandria Swimming Club was held on Saturday afternoon. The chief events of the meeting were a team race and polo match against H.M.S. "Diana." The team race, which was 420 yards, each member of the teams swimming 60 yards, was very well contested, but the club had got the better team together and won by a length and a half. After the team race was the polo match, which the club won by 6 goals to I, hut on this occasion a distinctly tatter match was witnessed, the "Diana" being much stronger than on the former occasion.The "Diana's" goal keeper was especially prominent and saved several difficult shots ; indeed, he was responsible for reducing the score by not a few goals. The polo match was followed by a 60 yards handicap between the members of the Club, which brought out 14 competitors. The handicap was divided into two heats, the winners of which were (I) Inglott and Liggins, and (2) Palmer and Darton. The final was won easily by Inglott who came in first by about five feet, hut only a touch separated second and third, who were Palmer and Liggins, respectively. The Club hope to hold a water carnival next Saturday in honour of the visit of the Mediterranean Fleet, which will arrive the previous day.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The object of Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan's visit to Constantinople is to get the permission of the Sultan to cruise among the Turkish islands in the Aegean Sea. As soon as the permit is accorded, the Prince will return to Alexandria and start again on his yacht for a cruise.
Lord and Lady Cromer attended the memorial service, held by command of the King in the Chapel Royal, St James's Palace to the late Major-General Sir Arthur Ellis.

Lord and Lady Cromer also attended the State Bull at Buckingham Palace in honour of the King and Queen of Denmark. Lady Cromer had a white gown with touches of silver and a band of diamonds in her hair.
Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, who embarked yesterday for Europe on the Austrian Lloyd mailboat, is replaced as Regent and Prime Minister by Boutros Pasha Ghali.

Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, who has postponed his visit to Europe in consequence of the visit of the Mediterranean Fleet, will entertain the officers of the fleet at the Alexandria Sporting Club on Saturday. On Friday evening they will be given a banquet by Boutros Pasha Ghali, Regent and acting Prime Minister.

Sir Ernest Cassel's marble palace, Brook House, Park Lane, which he purchased from Lord Tweedmouth, after undergoing extensive alterations, is reputed to be the finest town house in London, and it is also said that there is not its equal either in Paris or New York. The house is a veritable palace of marble, Italian and Canadian. The statuary, with which the reconstructed Brook House abounds, is representative of the most famous masters. Everything in this luxurious Park-lane mansion is in accordance with the artistic taste of its owner and the architects, Messrs. White, Allom, & Co.
The death is announced of Lord Granville Gordon, who died after leaving Suez on his way from Aden. He was heir presumptive to the Marquisate of Huntley and brother to the present Marquis.

Mr. William Jackson Maltass, of Alexandria, has composed a valse entitled "Happy Memoires," which was played the other night for the Windsor Hotel and met with great success. It is a very charming piece of composition and augurs well for the future career of this gentleman as a composer.
Mustapha Pasha Kamel is leaving Alexandria on Wednesday next for Europe by the North German Lloyd's S.S. Schleswig.

Hafez Effendi Awad, Editor of "Al Minbar", who, it will be remembered acted as Mr. Robertson's, M.P, guide and mentor during the latter's recent visit to this country, is leaving on Wednesday for Europe and during his holiday intends to visit England in order to put his view on Egypt before the statesmen of the day.

div.head: THE SUDAN EXPRESS.
div.p: The "Sudan Times" states that the express train that left Khartoum North last Wednesday night was detained at the station some two hours after the scheduled time of its departure. Thorough inspection of the line was made before the train started in order to make sure that the line was in no way damaged by the rain. For a similar reason, the express due last Thursday night arrived two hours late.

div.p: By kind permission of Major C. A. Wilding, commanding, and officers of the 2nd B11. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the Band will play the following programme of music in the Esbekieh Gardens from 9 to 11 p.m. tomorrow:—

Polka—Trotzkopfehen—Faust. Regimental March - Khedivial Anthem. God Save the King. R. Watson Ramsey, Bandmaster.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman liner "Assiout" sailed hence Saturday afternoon for Liverpool with a general cargo including 4068 bales of Egyptian and 294 bales of Syrian cotton.
The Ellerman liner "Fabian" arrived last Saturday morning with a general cargo from Liverpool, Swansea and Oran.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head:
WINE-GROWING CRISIS
LEADER OF REBELLION REPENTS. DISTURBANCES STILL SERIOUS.

div.p: The Chamber of Deputies, by 357 votes to 233, voted confidence in. M. Clemenceau's policy of continuing the work of repression in the South. An excited debate took place, the Nationalists and Socialist attacking M. Clemenceau who defeated General Bailloud's action in not firing on, the mutineers, saying that the latter were not deserted. ,

General Turcas, commanding the infantry at Narbonne has been dismissed. He is believed to be responsible for firing on the people. The railway has been cut at Poulhan, thus preventing reinforcements from reaching Beviers. The sub-prefect intervened and was veiled and taken prisoner by 4.000 peasants. The telegraphs and telephones have been cut at several other points. (Reuter)
Fresh disorders took place at Montpellier yesterday. Revolver firing continued until midnight. Cavalry charges were made. .Several were wounded. Many arrests were made.
According to an official bulletin the casualties at Narbonne amount to 7 deaths; 62 soldiers and 21 civilians have been wounded.
15 more regiments of infantry and 7 of cavalry are being sent South.
Rioting at Nimes occurred yesterday evening.
In order to enable immediate application and avoid delay, the Chamber to-day hastily passed, as a complete bill, the clauses of the Wine Bill which had already been adopted, reserving the remainder.
M. Fallieres proposed visit to Bordeaux has been deferred till September. All Ministers' public arrangement have been cancelled. (R.)
In consequence of the events Mr. Fallieres has adjourned his voyage to Norway.
The Chamber has voted the articles of law on the frauds adopted, leaving over some to be discussed, for immediately allaying the insis.
The mutineers of Agde returned in the morning to barracks.
The day has been calm in the wine-growing districts. (Haras)

M. Albert, unaccompanied, appeared this morning at the Ministry of Inferior. M. Clemenceau sternly rebuked him pointing out the heavy responsibility he incurred. M. Albert wept and asked his advice, exclaiming that if he could only make reparation be would do so. M. Clemenceau laconically recommended him to surrender to the authorities. M. Albert left by a private door. (Reuter)

M. Marcellin Albert appeared at the Ministry of the Interior. He was received by M. Clemenceau, who greatly blamed his conduct. M. Albert wept and asked advice. M. Clemenceau invited him to make himself prisoner M. Albert promised to issue his influence for restoring calm. He then left free and in the evening left for the South. (Haras)

Sir George Farrar's motion condemning General Botha's policy has been defeated by 45 votes to 21. Sir. Smuts emphasized the necessity for the repatriation, of, the Chinese. He appealed to the magnates to face the inevitable and not to plunge the country into ruin. (Reuter)

div.head: THE BALLOON ACCIDENT. LIEUR CAULFIELDS BODY RECOVERED.

div.p: The body of Lieutenant Caulfield, the missing balloonist has been picked up by fishermen at West Bay. (Reuter)

Kent bent Hampshire by an innings and 120 runs. The South Africans beat Derbyshire by an innings and 108 runs. Lancashire beat Sussex by 307 runs. Yorkshire beat Essex by 5 wickets. The following matches have been drawn ; Middlesex v. Surrey and Worcester shire v. Somerset. (Reuter)

The victims were secretly buried by the police at night. Censorship is most rigid. Indirect telegrams show that the anti monarchical movement is growing. The King and the Premier retain an uncompromising attitude. The King has authorized the governors to -suppress the newspapers if necessary. (Reuter)

The opinion prevails here that the present situation cannot continue. It is exited that Senor Franco's cabinet will shortly be replaced by a cabinet of conciliation representing all monarchist parties. (Reuter)
The rumour of the assassination of the Tsar is false. (Havas)

div.head:
CYPRUS.
A SUMMER RESORT FOR EGYPT.
div.p: The complaint is often made by Europeans in Egypt that one of the great drawbacks of life in this country is that no change can be found in the summer save what is obtainable at the cost of an expensive trip to Europe. Yet only a few hours distant lies one of the most beautiful islands in the Mediterranean, where all the expenses of a fortnight's visit need not exceed a single, first-class fare from Alexandria to Marseilles. No more charming or convenient summer resort than Cyprus can be found for those who do not care to face the expense and trouble of a trip to Europe. The sea journey only lasts a few hours and is invariably calm in the summer months.

The only English company leaving a frequent and regular service to Cyprus is the Asia Minor Steamship Company, which dispatches a steamer from Alexandria direct to Cyprus every eight day's. Only one whole day is spent at sea. The ports visited by the steamer are Limassol, Larnaca and Famagusta and there is time for passengers making the round trip to visit each port There is also a Greek line, the Limassol Steamship Company, running between Egypt and Cyprus.

The pine-clad heights of Mount Troodos, over 6,400 feet above the sea, are specially adapted for a long stay, while a hurried visitor can s pend a fortnight on the island, and, if he mAps out his tour, will find that in scenery and antiquarian interest Cyprus can hold its own with any country on the shores of the Mediterranean. The sites of its many ancient cities contain little of interest except to the archeologist, and scanty are the remains at Paphos and Salamis to tell of the glories of the cities of Aphrodite and Pygmalion. The real charm of Cyprus is not classic but romantic and medieval. The wonderful castles perched on mountain tops the cathedrals and churches of the Crusaders and Lusignan Kings, the old walled cities of Famagusta and Nicosia and the exquisite ruins of the Abbey of Bella Pais are filled with romantic mementoes extending from the age of knight errantry and Richard Coeur de Lion, to the last days of the Oriental Empire of the Republic of Venice The inland Is full of natural beauties. Along the northern coast the range of the Kyrenian mountains runs for over a hundred miles. Although their highest summit does not much exceed 3,000 feet, as they rise from the level of the sea, they look of quite an imposing altitude and they have all the pictures que contours of the mountains of Greece. Mount Troodos, the highest summit of the southern range, is the most delightful spot in the summer within a few hours journey from Egypt, and further to the west lies the beautiful region of the Paphos forest There is only the line of railway running from Famagusta to Nicosiaand Morphou on the west coast, but the roads are excellent and perfectly adapted every where for carriages. But the best node of seeing Cyprus is by means of a mule. Two mules, one for the tourist the other for the mulateer and the luggage, only cost 5s. per day. The country is perfectly safe to travel in and ladies can contemplate a visit to Cypress without the slightest anxiety. It is possible to see all the chief sights in the island in eight days, and thus a hasty visit will admit of the tourist gaining a good general impression of the island and being hack again in Alexandria in fortnight. Within eight days it will be possible to see Famagusta and Nicosia, to ride to Kyrenia and visit the castle of Saint Hilarion and the abbey of Bella Pais, to make a days excursion to the castle of Buffavento and to ride to Troodos and thence to Nicosia.

A fortnight's trip on the Island will enable the tourist to visit the castle of Kautara from Famagusta, and to stay two days at the beautifully situated monastery of Kykko, which will enable him to make a day's excursion to the Paphos forest while the time that remains before embarkation can be well spent on Mount Troodos.
HOTELS IN CYPRUS.

The hotels in Cyprus have much improved during the last few years and the accommodation is on the whole very fair, while they are generally dean and well kept, although they are, of course, of modest dimensions and cannot be compared with Egypt. The charges are moderate and the cost for full board and lodging, with the exception of Mount Troodos which has only a summer season, average about 6s per day. Even at Troodos for a long stay married couple can lie accommodated for 6s. 6d. a day or £10 per month.

There is excellent accommodation at Troodos for visitors. Mr. Najem Houry, the Army contractor, opened the Mount Olympus Hotel last year. It is beautifully situated and commands a magnificent view of the north of Cyprus. the hotel has twenty-two bedrooms, but tourists, who prefer, can be lodged in tents, which is a favourite mode of living on the mountain. The hotel is very comfortable and scrupulously clean and the charges for full board are from 6s. to 10s. per day. For long stays there are special terms. This is the only hotel on the mountain, but Miss Young, an English lady from Nicosia, accommodates visitors in her camp doling the summer months under canvas.

Mr. Najem Houry also owns the Savoy Hotel at Famagusta It is situated on rising ground over looking the sea and is near the English Club and the Railway Station. It only patronized by Europeans and is quite comfortable Visitors landing at Famagusta, Larnaca or Limassol can have all their arrangements for a trip to Troodos made through Mr. Najem Houry. The Armenian Hotel at Nicosia is a well managed establishment and the proprietor, Mr. George Sultanian, is most obliging and has a large English clientele. At Limassol there are two hotels, the Britannia Hotel, belonging to Mr. Selim Houry, and the Troodos Hotel, which is the property Mr. Nikola Cyprioti. The Royal Hotel at Larnaca is also a comfortable establishment. One of the places in the island, which all tourists should visit, is Kyrenia owing to its proximity to the magnificent remains of the Castle of Saint Hilarion and the monastery of Bella Pais. A new hotel, the Akteon, has lately been built there. It is right on the sea and has a bathing establishment attached.

div.head: BAHR EL GHAZAL
div.p: The "Sudan Times" gives the following gist of an interview with a gentleman who has been in Bahr el Ghazal, ament the conditions of that vast province:

"Though nearer the equator than Khartom, the heat there is not more intense, and the nights are always cool, sometimes cold. The country is thickly wooded and the ground is covered with grass. The atmosphere therefore deer on account of the absence of dust.

The rainy season lasts about 8 months, during which, though the rain falls at frequent intervals it rarely lasts more than one or two hours. During the dry season, the ground remains covered with green grass.

The soil is suitable for the cultivation of all products that are raised in other parts of the country. Vegetables, such as potatoes, tomatoes, beans, peas, etc, have been tried and thrived admirably. Sugar cane and bananas, if cultivated there, may become profitable industries.
Cotton may be successfully planted.Several plants were seen, probably descended from seeds brought during the former occupation of the country by the Government. The staple

short, but the bolls are as soft os silk, and if proper care is taken, there is every reason to believe that cotton can be cultivated with profit especially as no artificial irrigation is required, the rainy season of eight mouths being amply sufficient.

The climate is not bad. A fair attention to the plain rules of health enables one to avoid any serious illness. Indeed one may live there several years without contracting any sickness. Among the most efficient means for preserving good health are daily warm baths and physical exercise or manual labour. Tiresome labour, however, should be avoided during the hottest part of the day, or in the sun. The weather changes suddenly and precautions must lie taken against the sudden changes.

The natives are usually strongly built Their muscles are well-developed like those of athletes. This is attributed mainly to their simple mode of life and their indulgence in dancing. To most of the men, this is the only form of exercise they have, as they do no bodily labour, relegating the cultivation on the fields and the carrying of burdens and similar hard work to the women.

Malaria is prevalent in the swamps, but is rather scarce in Meridi and its neighbourhood. Gigger worms are perhaps the worst pest; but they can be easily avoided by cleanliness and by never walking barefooted.

The main obstacles in the way of the development of those regions at present are due to the difficulty of communications and the absence of good roads. But the efforts that the Government is putting forth to improve the roads raise the hopes that before long that part of the Sudan will not be behind the rest of the country in its march towards civilization and prosperity.

div.head: THE SLEEPING SICKNESS.
div.p: INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE CONVENED.

An important step forward in the campaign against sleeping sickness has been taken by the British Colonial Office in convening a conference of the various African colonies and protectorates interested, to discuss international measures for dealing with this dread scourge. the first meeting took place at the Foreign Office last week, when the delegates were as follows Great Britain, Lord Fitz maurice, who has been elected president. Sir W. Foster, Mr. A.W. Clarke, Foreign Office, Mr. H. J. Read, Colonial Office, and Sir Patrick Man son; Sudan, Colonel Hunter and Dr. Balfour, of the Garden College, Khartum Germany, Herr von Jacobs, of the Imperial Colonial Office, Dr. Ehrlich and Dr. Fulleborn Congo Free State, Colonel Lantonnais, Vice Governor General, Commandant Tonneau, M, Rotten, and Dr. van Campenhout ; Frances Dr. Kermorgant, Dr. Paul Gonzion, Professor Blanchard, and Dr. Laveran; and Portugal, Dr. Correa Pinto.

The work before the conference includes the question of the bolding of regular conferences, the establishment of a central bureau of information, the assignment of definite points for investigation to particular countries or individuals. In the case of Uganda, Mr. Hesketh Bell, his Majesty's Commissioner for the Protectorate, has prepared a scheme for dealing with the scourge in his Protectorate. The main features of the scheme are the deportation of the population from the infected lake shore and the segregation of the sick in a number of large camps, where they can be treated by atoxyl or other drugs which give hope for success.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
div.p: POLO

A very keen polo match was played at Ghezireh, on Thursday last, the 20th inst. The team were the Veterans r the World. It resulted in a tie, one goal all. It was a very creditable performance on the part of the Veterans, as a very strong team opposed them.
The teams were as follows :—
Veterans.
Major Stephenson I.
Mr. Marsham II.
Major Haig, (K.O.S.B.), III.
Major Neil Haig (back).
The World.
Capt. Stirling I.
„ Bartlett II.
Mr. Bentinck III.
„ Bowen back.
For the Veterans Major Neil Haig was a tower of strength to his side. For the World Copt Bartlett and Mr. Bowen were conspicuous. All however played in good form and each did their share.

La Municipality met an adjudication les travaux de construction d'une annexe au Palais Municipal.
Le cautionnement est fixe a L. Eg Quatre-Cents (400).
Le cashier des charges est despose au Bureau Technique ou il peut être consulte par les interesses tous les jours de 9 h. a midi, les jours fériés exceptis.
Les offres devront être adresses sous pli cacheté 4 Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipality avant le 9 Juillet 1907.
Elles pourront également etre desposees en seance de la Delegation le meme jour 4 5 h. p.m
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : "Sou mission pour travaux d'une annexe au Palais Municipal."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis separement au Service de la Comptabilite Generale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 9 Juillet 1907 4 midi.
